study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of breaking sitting with standing and light-intensity walking versus structured exercise on 24-hour glucose levels and insulin resistance in patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that breaking sitting with standing and light-intensity walking significantly improved 24-hour glucose levels and insulin sensitivity compared to prolonged sitting, and was similarly effective to structured exercise for glucose control but superior for insulin sensitivity.
population_specificity: 19 patients with type 2 diabetes (13 men, 6 women, average age 63 ± 9 years) not using insulin.
effective_dosage: Sit Less regimen involved replacing 4.7 hours/day of sitting with standing (2.5 hours) and light-intensity walking (2.2 hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of pulsed radiofrequency (PRF) versus thermal radiofrequency (TRF) applied to the medial calcaneal nerve for treating chronic refractory plantar fasciitis pain.
results_summary: PRF provided significantly better pain relief and satisfaction scores at 1 and 3 weeks compared to TRF, with effective analgesia achieved faster (within one week for PRF vs. three weeks for TRF). Both treatments showed sustained pain improvement for 24 weeks.
population_specificity: 20 patients with refractory chronic bilateral plantar fasciitis.
effective_dosage: PRF for 6 minutes on one heel, TRF for 90 seconds on the other heel.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to resolve the debate on whether ankle push-off during walking primarily contributes to leg swing acceleration or center of mass (COM) acceleration.
results_summary: The study found that ankle push-off contributes to both leg swing acceleration and COM acceleration, demonstrating that these effects are not mutually exclusive. It highlighted that the localized segmental acceleration of the trailing limb also accelerates the COM, unifying previously polarized perspectives.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human walking mechanics)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of step-aerobic exercise (SAE) and jogging-walking exercise (JWE) on myokines and adipokines levels in overweight sedentary females.
results_summary: JWE increased leptin and IL-15 levels while decreasing resistin after 12 weeks. SAE showed higher TNF-α, IL-15, and IL-18 levels but lower leptin compared to JWE. Neither exercise significantly altered IL-17, IL-6, or adiponectin levels.
population_specificity: Overweight sedentary females (N=25)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of the 2012 European Cosmetic Directive on non-vital bleaching practices, including the "walking" technique, in restorative dentistry.
results_summary: The study found that clinicians reported similar clinical outcomes despite restrictions on hydrogen peroxide concentration, though 50% noted more treatment visits were needed for acceptable results. Concerns were raised about the psychological impact of banning treatment for patients under 18 with discolored teeth.
population_specificity: Dentists and patients in the Belfast and Cork restorative departments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a clinical score to predict appendicitis in older male children presenting to the emergency department with suspected appendicitis, using variables including pain with walking/coughing or hopping.
results_summary: The study found that pain with walking/coughing or hopping was one of the variables retained in the predictive model for appendicitis. A score ≥8.1 had high specificity (98%) and positive predictive value (93%) for ruling in appendicitis.
population_specificity: Male patients aged 8-18 years presenting to pediatric emergency departments with suspected appendicitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether progressive treadmill walking exercise training improves learning, memory, and hippocampal viscoelasticity in persons with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found small-to-moderate improvements in learning and memory (CVLT-II performance) and large improvements in hippocampal viscoelastic properties (shear stiffness and damping ratio). Changes in memory scores were strongly correlated with changes in hippocampal properties.
population_specificity: Fully ambulatory females with multiple sclerosis (MS).
effective_dosage: Supervised, progressive treadmill walking exercise training (specific intensity/frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of a new fall prevention program incorporating Shubert's recommendations with usual physical therapy in reducing fall risk among older adults.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significantly greater reductions in fall risk and higher exercise compliance compared to the usual care group, exceeding the target exercise duration of 115 minutes per week.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged 65+ with walking difficulties or instability and at least one fall risk factor.
effective_dosage: 30-minute PT sessions twice weekly for 10-32 visits, plus a home exercise program targeting 115+ minutes per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of two levels of integrated care (low-level and high-level) on improving frailty and sarcopenia in older adults, with walking as a component of the exercise program.
results_summary: The study found that both low-level and high-level care improved frailty and sarcopenia, with high-level care showing greater improvements in walking-related metrics (energy expenditure, walking time, grip strength, and balance tests) at 6 and 12 months.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (65-79 years) with frailty (scoring ≥1 on CHS_PCF).
effective_dosage: High-level care included 48 exercise sessions over 6 months (frequency not specified).
study_duration: 6 months (with follow-up assessments at 3, 6, and 12 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the correlation between exertional dyspnea scales (EDS) and exercise capacity (including walking distance) in COPD patients, as well as evaluate the best combination of EDS and health-related quality-of-life questionnaires (HRQoLQs).
results_summary: The study found that EDS was more strongly correlated with exercise capacity (including walking distance) than with dyspnea perception. The Oxygen-cost Diagram (OCD) showed the strongest correlation with walking distance, while the COPD assessment test (CAT) was poorly correlated with walking distance but strongly correlated with other HRQoLQs.
population_specificity: 57 patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a telephone-based behavioral counseling intervention (Step-up to Quit) could increase daily low-to-moderate physical activity (walking) among low-income, physically inactive smokers.
results_summary: The Step-up to Quit (SUTQ) intervention significantly increased physical activity, with participants achieving higher daily step counts (7,207 vs. 3,947) and more reaching the 7,500 steps/day goal (49% vs. 11%) compared to controls. These effects were sustained at follow-up, though the intervention's impact on smoking cue reactivity was not significant.
population_specificity: Low-income, physically inactive smokers (51% female, 77% African-American, mean age 42.1 years).
effective_dosage: Goal of achieving 7,500 steps/day by week 4.
study_duration: 4 weeks of counseling prior to smoking quit day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the anatomy, diagnostic imaging, and clinical management of injuries and pathologies affecting the first and lesser metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint complexes, particularly in relation to walking and sports.
results_summary: The study highlights the importance of the MTP joint complex in walking and sports, common injuries like "turf toe," and conditions such as arthritis or infection that can affect these joints. It emphasizes the role of imaging in diagnosing and managing these conditions.
population_specificity: American football and soccer players, and individuals with degenerative or inflammatory arthritis, infarct, or infection affecting the MTP joints.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate gait improvements in people with Parkinson disease after a hydrotherapy program using 2D and 3D underwater and on land gait analysis.
results_summary: The study found that underwater gait training led to significant improvements in spatiotemporal parameters and lower limb kinematics in parkinsonians, with 3D analysis showing improvements across all movement planes. Baseline comparisons showed parkinsonians had shorter stride length and slower speed than controls, which improved post-treatment.
population_specificity: Thirty-four parkinsonians and twenty-two controls, divided into two cohorts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess and compare the performance of four kinematic-based gait event detection algorithms during walking on surfaces with different degrees of planarity.
results_summary: The study found that surface configuration affected algorithm accuracy, with the vertical foot-velocity profile providing the lowest RMSE for footstrike during normal walking and toe-off during both normal and fast walking. The horizontal heel-ankle displacement algorithm performed best for footstrike during fast walking.
population_specificity: Thirteen athletes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different prosthetic feet on energy costs and ambulatory performance in transfemoral amputees.
results_summary: The study found that energy costs were higher and ambulatory performance was lower for transfemoral amputees compared to non-amputee controls across all prosthetic foot conditions. Energy storing and return feet, particularly running-specific ones, improved walking performance by enabling faster self-selected walking speeds.
population_specificity: Transfemoral amputees

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether walking, alone or combined with HRT, affects bone turnover in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Walking alone at the prescribed intensity and duration did not change bone turnover markers, nor did it provide additional benefits when combined with HRT. HRT reduced bone resorption, but walking had no significant effect.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women
effective_dosage: Graduated walking regimen (increased intensity, duration, and frequency from weeks 8-20)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of sarcopenia in muscle function, particularly walking speed, and the hormonal and therapeutic factors influencing it.
results_summary: The study found that sarcopenia, linked to reduced walking speed, is influenced by hormones like testosterone, growth hormone, insulin, and vitamin D, with treatments including resistance exercise, leucine-enriched amino acids, and vitamin D replacement.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling and long-term care populations (prevalence 1-33%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and evaluate studies reporting the psychometric properties of patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) to recommend suitable PROMs for clinical and research use.
results_summary: The review identified 14 studies evaluating 6 generic and 7 condition-specific PROMs, with the SF-36, Walking Impairment Questionnaire, EQ-5D, and Vascular Quality of Life Questionnaire being the most frequently reported. No study provided a full psychometric evaluation of PROMs in the PAD population.
population_specificity: English-speaking patients with various stages of peripheral arterial disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two physical rehabilitation interventions (augmented mobilisation physiotherapy and in-bed cycling) on walking ability and activities of daily living in patients with ICU-acquired weakness due to CIM and/or CIP.
results_summary: The study is a planned RCT, so no results are reported in the abstract. The primary outcomes will assess walking ability and functional status after 2 weeks of additional therapy, with follow-ups at 3 weeks, 6 months, and 12 months.
population_specificity: Patients with ICU-acquired weakness (ICUAW) and a defined diagnosis of critical illness myopathy (CIM) and/or polyneuropathy (CIP) in a post-acute hospital setting.
effective_dosage: Physiotherapy (5 times/week, 20 min/session, 10 sessions total) or in-bed cycling (same frequency and duration).
study_duration: 2 weeks of additional therapy, with follow-ups up to 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and impact of a Nordic walking program on cardiovascular risk factors, quality of life, and treatment adherence in patients with chronic ischemic heart disease or metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study observed a reduction in cardiovascular risk factors from 4.78 to 3, along with improvements in quality of life and treatment adherence. The program was deemed feasible in a public healthcare setting.
population_specificity: Patients with uncontrolled cardiovascular risk factors, specifically those with chronic ischemic heart disease or metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of statin use on cardiovascular events, mortality, and limb-related outcomes in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD), including its impact on walking distance and time.
results_summary: Statins slightly improved pain-free walking distance or time in PAD patients, but the effect on quality of life was unclear. Revascularization rates decreased with statin use, but amputation rates and amputation-free survival did not improve.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
effective_dosage: Moderate-dose statin therapy (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether modified-release fampridine improves walking distance in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant 17-meter improvement in the six-minute walk test (6MWT) with fampridine treatment. Additionally, baseline nerve excitability parameters may help identify patients most likely to benefit from fampridine.
population_specificity: 25 patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of active mobilisation and rehabilitation (including walking) in the ICU on mortality, function, mobility, muscle strength, quality of life, and other outcomes.
results_summary: Active mobilisation and rehabilitation improved muscle strength at ICU discharge, increased the probability of walking without assistance at hospital discharge, and resulted in more days alive and out of hospital by 180 days, but had no impact on mortality, function, quality of life, or other secondary outcomes.
population_specificity: ICU patients (total of 1753 patients across 14 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize the literature on walking interventions for pediatric spinal cord injury (SCI) to guide future clinical trials and interventions.
results_summary: The study found that intensive walking training, particularly overground practice, resulted in notable improvements in walking capacity, speed, and distance for children with SCI, comparable to gains seen in adults. However, the quality of pediatric studies was generally low, with high risk of bias.
population_specificity: Children aged 1-17 years with post-birth spinal cord injury (SCI).
study_duration: Not specified (total training duration was calculated as duration × frequency × number of weeks, but exact lengths varied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of body weight-supported treadmill training (BWSTT) for improving walking recovery in spinal cord injury (SCI) and discuss its limitations in translating to real-world walking.
results_summary: The study found that BWSTT, while promising in animal models, has shown limited success in humans with SCI for overground walking. It introduced a new device (Circular BART) for weight-supported overground walking in rats, highlighting its simplicity and cost-effectiveness.
population_specificity: Humans and animals (rats) with spinal cord injury (SCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical characteristics and health status between COPD patients who spontaneously produced sputum (with positive or negative cultures) and those who did not.
results_summary: The study found that spontaneous sputum production was common in COPD patients, with those having positive cultures showing worse health status, more symptoms of depression, and more frequent exacerbations compared to non-sputum producers.
population_specificity: 518 clinically stable COPD patients (mild-to-very severe, mean age 64.1±9.1 years, 55.6% male).

study_goal: The researchers investigated left ventricular myocardial changes associated with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) using cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) techniques, including strain analysis and mapping.
results_summary: The study found that patients with PAH had higher T1-relaxation times and extracellular volume fraction, lower left ventricular longitudinal strain, and reduced LV mass and septal thickness compared to controls, suggesting myocardial fibrosis and atrophy. The 6-minute walking distance was correlated with T1-derived parameters, but the study did not focus on walking as an intervention.
population_specificity: 17 patients with PAH (9 men; mean age 64.2±13.6 years) and 20 controls (10 men; mean age 63.2±10.5 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify prognostic predictors for ambulation in children with cerebral palsy through a meta-analysis of observational studies.
results_summary: The study found that sitting independently at 2 years, absence of visual impairment, intellectual disability, and epilepsy or seizure were significant positive predictors for ambulation in children with cerebral palsy.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of teriparatide and risedronate on recovery, including walking ability, after pertrochanteric hip fractures.
results_summary: Teriparatide was associated with a shorter time to complete the Timed Up-and-Go (TUG) test and less pain compared to risedronate, but no significant differences were found in walking ability, use of walking aids, or other fracture-recovery outcomes.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (mean age 77 ± 8 years, 77% female) with low-trauma pertrochanteric hip fractures and low bone mineral density (T-score ≤ -2.0).
study_duration: 26 weeks of active treatment (total study duration 78 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a slow-jogging program, combined with walking, on skeletal muscle, fat infiltration, and fitness in older adults.
results_summary: The 12-week slow-jogging program improved aerobic capacity, muscle function, and muscle composition in older adults, with significant reductions in subcutaneous and intermuscular adipose tissue and increased intracellular water in the legs.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling, independent older adults (average age 70.8 ± 4.0 years).
effective_dosage: 90 minutes of slow-jogging at anaerobic threshold intensity and 90 minutes of walking intermittently per week.

study_goal: The researchers sought to quantify physical activity outside structured therapy sessions during inpatient SCI rehabilitation and examine changes over time from admission to discharge.
results_summary: The study found no change in self-reported physical activity, with most time spent in sedentary leisure activities. However, accelerometer data showed significant increases in physical activity outside therapy for individuals with tetraplegia (upper limb activity) and ambulatory individuals (walking activity).
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI) undergoing inpatient rehabilitation, categorized into paraplegia, tetraplegia, and ambulatory subgroups.
study_duration: From admission to discharge (specific duration not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how lateral wedge insoles affect 3D resultant knee moments during walking in individuals with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Lateral wedges significantly reduced peak frontal-plane and 3D resultant knee moments, but 25% of participants experienced increased 3D moments despite reduced frontal-plane moments, suggesting inconsistent effects on total knee load.
population_specificity: 20 individuals with knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of a home-based biomechanical treatment program (AposTherapy) on pain, function, and gait parameters in patients with spontaneous osteonecrosis of the knee (SONK).
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in pain (53%) and functional limitation (43%), along with improvements in gait velocity (41% increase), step length (22% increase), and limb symmetry after 3 and 6 months of therapy. Patients also showed enhanced physical and mental health scores on the SF-36.
population_specificity: Seventeen patients with MRI-confirmed spontaneous osteonecrosis of the knee (SONK).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the applicability and effectiveness of the CPWalker robotic platform in improving gait rehabilitation and postural control in children with spastic diplegia.
results_summary: After ten sessions of personalized training with CPWalker, children showed significant improvements in mean velocity (51.94%), cadence (29.19%), and step length (26.49%). Post-3D gait assessments indicated kinematic outcomes closer to normal values compared to pre-assessments.
population_specificity: Children with spastic diplegia (a form of Cerebral Palsy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if repetitive task training (RTT) improves upper and lower limb function, including walking, in adults after stroke.
results_summary: The study found low- to moderate-quality evidence that RTT improves walking distance and functional ambulation, with effects sustained up to six months post-treatment. No significant differences were observed beyond six months, and effects were not influenced by intervention type, dosage, or time since stroke.
population_specificity: Adults after stroke.
study_duration: Varied by study; follow-up data assessed up to six months post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine differences in kinematic gait parameters and Knee Society Score between patients with cruciate-retaining and posterior-substituting total knee arthroplasty.
results_summary: The study found no differences in gait parameters or Knee Society Score between the two surgical groups, and both groups showed similar gait alterations to patients with knee osteoarthritis, differing significantly from healthy individuals.
population_specificity: Patients after total knee arthroplasty (cruciate-retaining and posterior-substituting), patients with knee osteoarthritis, and healthy individuals.
study_duration: Several months post-surgery (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a two-week treatment with cerebellar anodal tDCS could improve symptoms in patients with neurodegenerative cerebellar ataxia and modulate cerebello-motor connectivity.
results_summary: Patients who underwent anodal tDCS showed significant improvement in performance scores (e.g., walking time) and cerebellar brain inhibition compared to sham stimulation, with effects observed at short and long-term follow-ups.
population_specificity: Twenty patients with neurodegenerative cerebellar ataxia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the reproducibility of walking variables under single-task and dual-task conditions and identify confounding effects of gait velocity, age, and gender on peak plantar pressure.
results_summary: The study found excellent reproducibility of walking variables under both conditions (ICC values .67 to .99). Plantar pressure was influenced by gait velocity but less by age and gender, and differences between preferred and fixed gait speeds during dual-task walking needed control to isolate dual-task effects.
population_specificity: Seniors (N = 86, mean age 71.9 ± 4.6 years)
effective_dosage: Not applicable (gait analysis at self-selected and fixed speeds: 3.5 and 4.5 km/h)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a neuro-muscular exercise program (NEMEX) versus optimized analgesic and anti-inflammatory drug use (PHARMA) on knee joint load during walking in individuals with mild to moderate knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in knee joint load changes during walking between the NEMEX and PHARMA groups. Secondary outcomes, including peak knee adduction moment and functional performance, also showed no notable differences.
population_specificity: Individuals with mild-to-moderate medial tibiofemoral knee osteoarthritis (57% women, average age 58 ± 8 years, BMI 27 ± 4 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: NEMEX therapy twice a week; PHARMA involved optimized use of analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs (specific dosages not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess functional outcomes and patient satisfaction after a combined FHL transfer and gastrocnemius recession for treating chronic Achilles tendon ruptures with a gap.
results_summary: The study found significant improvement in AOFAS scores from 65 preoperatively to 94 postoperatively, with no reported big toe dysfunction. The procedure was deemed safe and reliable, with no significant difference in outcomes between tendon weaving and trans osseous tunnel methods.
population_specificity: 19 patients with chronic Achilles tendon ruptures and a gap.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a balance group exercise programme (CoDuSe) on balance and walking in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: The exercise group showed statistically significant improvement in balance (Berg Balance Scale) and borderline significant improvement in perceived walking limitations (MS Walking Scale). The intervention also significantly reduced falls and near falls frequency in the group starting late.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (Expanded Disability Status Scale 4.0-7.5).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a physical exercise program, including walking, could improve or maintain activities of daily living (ADL) scores in patients with moderate to severe dementia during acute psychiatric hospitalization.
results_summary: The exercise program, which included walking, delayed the loss of mobility-related ADL scores but did not significantly impact overall ADL scores compared to the control group. The control group showed a significant decline in ADL scores over time.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate to severe dementia hospitalized in acute psychiatric wards in Swiss and Belgian hospitals.
effective_dosage: 20 physical exercise sessions (strengthening, balance, and walking) over four weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of functional electrical stimulation (FES) in reducing falls and improving lower limb kinematics (foot clearance and energy recovery) during walking in people with multiple sclerosis and stroke.
results_summary: The study found that FES reduced the number of falls and increased foot clearance during walking, but did not significantly improve energy recovery.
population_specificity: 14 people with multiple sclerosis and 10 people with stroke.
effective_dosage: Daily home walking training using FES (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of liraglutide, sitagliptin, and insulin glargine on left ventricular function in post-ischemic type-2 diabetes mellitus patients, not specifically on walking.
results_summary: The study found that liraglutide improved left ventricular ejection fraction and functional capacity, while sitagliptin and insulin glargine showed no significant changes. Walking was assessed via a 6-minute walking test, but results specific to walking were not highlighted.
population_specificity: 32 type-2 diabetes mellitus Caucasians with post-ischemic chronic heart failure (NYHA class II/III or left ventricular ejection fraction ≤45%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of a brief behavioral counselling intervention to improve physical activity (specifically interval walking) in people with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study will assess whether behavioral counselling promotes interval walking (3 × 40 min/week) and improves outcomes such as physical activity, walking capacity, and quality of life, with evaluations at baseline, 4, 12, and 24 months.
population_specificity: Adults with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) recruited from vascular clinics, general practitioners, and research databases in Australia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of human mesenchymal stromal cells (hMSC) and human mononuclear cells (hMNC) in treating rat cerebral infarct.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results related to Walking.
population_specificity: SD rat models of cerebral infarct.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether computerized cognitive remediation could improve mobility (measured by gait speed) in seniors compared to computer-based health education training.
results_summary: The study will assess changes in gait speed during normal walking and walking-while-talking conditions, along with secondary outcomes like mobility-related cognitive processes and neuroplasticity, but final results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: 420 seniors with mobility disabilities

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to highlight the variability in treatment for lumbar spinal stenosis and the need for a classification system to guide treatment and research.
results_summary: The abstract notes that lumbar spinal stenosis causes pain, cramping, and weakness in the legs, worsened by walking, and that surgery improves health-related quality of life, but treatment approaches vary widely due to the lack of a classification system.
population_specificity: Patients with lumbar spinal stenosis, most commonly in the sixth or seventh decade of life.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of endurance training (ET) and resistance training (RT) on quadriceps muscle characteristics, symptom burden, and exercise capacity in COPD patients.
results_summary: Both ET and RT improved symptom burden and exercise capacity, with no significant difference between the two groups. ET specifically reduced glycolytic type IIa muscle fibers, promoting a more oxidative muscle phenotype.
population_specificity: Thirty COPD patients with a forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) of 56% predicted.
effective_dosage: Not specified (training modalities: ET and RT for 8 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week exercise intervention, including home-based walking and weekly counseling, could improve sleep quality and rest-activity rhythms in lung cancer patients.
results_summary: The walking program significantly improved subjective sleep quality (PSQI) and objective sleep measures (TST, SE, SOL, WASO) as well as rest-activity rhythms (r24 and I<O) in lung cancer patients. The effects were sustained at 3 and 6 months post-intervention.
population_specificity: 111 lung cancer patients
effective_dosage: Not specified (home-based walking exercise training and weekly exercise counseling)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of exercise on gait speed in people with dementia, comparing outcomes when walking aids were used versus when they were not.
results_summary: The study found no overall between-group differences in gait speed at 4 or 7 months. However, positive exercise effects on gait speed were observed in subgroups that walked unsupported, suggesting walking aid use may conceal exercise benefits.
population_specificity: 141 women and 45 men (mean age 85 years) with dementia living in nursing homes, 78% of whom habitually used walking aids.
effective_dosage: High-intensity functional exercise program (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of adductor canal block (ACB) and femoral nerve block (FNB) on quadriceps muscle strength and ambulation in patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty, from early postoperative results up to 6 months.
results_summary: ACB showed significantly better preservation of quadriceps muscle strength and improved ambulation in the first 24 hours postoperatively compared to FNB, without compromising pain control. No significant differences were found in pain scores, medication intake, range of motion, or 6-minute walking test between the groups.
population_specificity: 98 patients (93 analyzed) undergoing total knee arthroplasty.
effective_dosage: 30 mL of local anesthetic (treatment) or saline (placebo), administered once.
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 6, 24, and 48 hours, and 6 months postoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the long-term safety and effectiveness of Omnitrope®, a somatropin biosimilar, in children with growth disturbances.
results_summary: The study found that Omnitrope® was generally well tolerated, with adverse events reported in 35.6% of patients, including gait disturbance and worsening of walking difficulties in one case. Treatment was associated with improvements in height and height velocity scores.
population_specificity: Children with growth disturbances, including growth hormone deficiency, small for gestational age, Prader-Willi syndrome, Turner syndrome, and chronic renal insufficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of morning treadmill walking versus hourly microbouts of walking on mood, energy, and cognitive function in sedentary office workers.
results_summary: Both morning walking and hourly microbouts increased energy and vigor, but only microbouts improved mood, reduced fatigue, and decreased food cravings. Cognitive function was unaffected by either intervention.
population_specificity: 30 sedentary adults
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of moderate-intensity treadmill walking in the morning (ONE) or six 5-minute microbouts spread across the day (MICRO)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether virtual reality-based treadmill training improves gait measures in individuals with multiple sclerosis compared to standard treadmill training.
results_summary: Both groups improved walking endurance, speed, cadence, stride length, and lower limb joint function, but the virtual reality group showed additional improvements in balance, hip range of motion, and hip power generation. The experimental group outperformed the control group in specific gait parameters.
population_specificity: Individuals with multiple sclerosis and mild to moderate disability (n=25).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether inspiratory muscle training (IMT) could improve functional fitness in obese adults by addressing breathlessness and physical performance.
results_summary: The study found that IMT significantly improved inspiratory muscle strength in the experimental group (19.1 cmH₂O increase) compared to the placebo group, suggesting it may enhance functional fitness and readiness for physical activity.
population_specificity: Adults with obesity (BMI=36±6.5).
effective_dosage: Daily use of an inspiratory resistance device set to 55% (experimental) or 10% (placebo) of maximum inspiratory effort.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the therapeutic benefits of ultrasound-guided intratissue percutaneous electrolysis (EPI) for rectus abdominis-related groin pain (RAGP) in professional footballers, focusing on pain reduction and functional recovery.
results_summary: EPI treatment led to complete pain reduction within one month and restored functional abilities—walking and jogging improved within one week, while more strenuous activities like running, jumping, and kicking recovered within one month.
population_specificity: Eight professional footballers from Udinese Calcio Spa Football Club.
study_duration: Follow-up assessments occurred at 24 hours, 1 week, 1 month, and 6 months post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and limited efficacy of the Ready~Steady intervention, which included walking as part of fall-reducing physical activities, in improving physical activity behavior and related outcomes.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvement in physical activity behavior compared to the control group, with low attrition (7%) and high attendance (7.2 of 8 sessions), indicating good acceptability and implementation fidelity.
population_specificity: Thirty participants from two rural communities in Itasca County, Minnesota, randomized into intervention (n=16) and attention-control (n=14) groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how specific training parameters (amount, intensity, variability) in rehabilitation interventions affect walking recovery poststroke.
results_summary: The study found that training parameters like amount, intensity, and variability of task practice influence walking recovery poststroke, with different patient subgroups benefiting from tailored emphasis on specific parameters. Conventional and assisted interventions may not fully optimize these variables, impacting outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients poststroke with varying degrees of impairment and stroke acuity.

study_goal: The researchers compared patient-reported outcomes (including walking ability) and reoperation rates between posterior and direct lateral surgical approaches for hemiarthroplasty in hip fracture patients.
results_summary: The posterior approach resulted in better patient-reported outcomes, including walking ability, compared to the direct lateral approach, with no significant difference in reoperation rates.
population_specificity: Patients aged 60 years and older who underwent hemiarthroplasty for femoral neck fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare knee joint biomechanics and muscle activation patterns during gait between asymptomatic and symptomatic individuals with the same radiographic grade of knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The symptomatic group exhibited higher knee adduction moments, lower peak flexion moments, and increased muscle activity in the lateral hamstrings and quadriceps during stance compared to the asymptomatic group, suggesting a "stiffer" gait pattern with potential implications for joint loading.
population_specificity: 54 asymptomatic and 59 symptomatic individuals with radiographic knee osteoarthritis (Kellgren-Lawrence grade 2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of Nordic walking on a treadmill on balance function and walking ability in individuals with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: Both Nordic walking training and treadmill training groups showed improvement in all measured outcomes, but the Nordic walking group exhibited significantly greater improvements in balance, walking ability, and motor function compared to the treadmill group.
population_specificity: Individuals with stage 1-3 Parkinson's disease on the Hoehn and Yahr scale.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a 4-week walking intervention on subjective sleep quality in healthy workers with and without exercise habits.
results_summary: The walking intervention improved overall sleep quality, including sleep latency, sleep duration, and perceived sleep quality, with more pronounced benefits in participants without prior exercise habits.
population_specificity: 490 healthy workers (214 with exercise habits, 276 without).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the long-term relationship between life satisfaction and surgical outcomes, including walking capacity, in lumbar spinal stenosis patients over a 10-year follow-up.
results_summary: The study found that both preoperative life dissatisfaction and long-term life dissatisfaction burden were associated with poorer 10-year surgical outcomes, including walking capacity. Life dissatisfaction was also linked to symptoms of depression.
population_specificity: 102 lumbar spinal stenosis patients who underwent decompressive surgery (72 completed the 10-year follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether an automatic oxygen titration system (FreeO₂) improves oxygenation and exercise tolerance during walking in COPD patients compared to fixed oxygen flow or room air.
results_summary: The study found that FreeO₂ significantly reduced the time with oxygen desaturation and improved oxygenation during walking compared to fixed oxygen or room air, suggesting potential benefits for exercise tolerance in daily activities.
population_specificity: Patients with COPD who exhibited oxygen desaturation on exertion.
effective_dosage: Oxygen at 2 L/min (fixed flow) and FreeO₂ (automatic titration).
study_duration: Endurance shuttle walk tests followed by 10 min of recovery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether virtual reality reflection therapy (VRRT) could improve postural balance and gait ability in patients with chronic stroke.
results_summary: The VRRT group showed statistically significant improvements in balance (BBS, FRT, TUG, postural sway) and gait ability (10 mWV) compared to the control group. The study concluded that VRRT combined with conventional rehabilitation is more beneficial than conventional rehabilitation alone for improving lower limb function in chronic stroke patients.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic stroke (n=25, VRRT group=13, control group=12).
effective_dosage: VRRT program for 30 minutes, five times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a gait rehabilitation program using augmented reality is superior to conventional treadmill training for improving walking capabilities in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study compared augmented reality gait training with standard treadmill training, measuring outcomes like walking speed, balance control, and fear of falling. Results will provide insights into the effectiveness of augmented reality in gait rehabilitation, though specific findings are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with reduced walking capability in a rehabilitation clinic setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the clinical features and progression of corticobasal degeneration, particularly its impact on walking and movement.
results_summary: The study found that corticobasal degeneration commonly affects gait, leading to progressive impairment in walking and movement, alongside other cortical signs like apraxia and dementia. Ocular symptoms may aid in distinguishing it from other parkinsonian syndromes.
population_specificity: Patients with corticobasal degeneration, a rare neurodegenerative disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of regional nerve blocks versus standard analgesics for pain management and mobility after hip fracture.
results_summary: The intervention group (nerve blocks) had significantly lower pain scores, walked farther on postoperative day 3, and reported better walking and stair-climbing ability at 6 weeks compared to controls. They also experienced fewer opioid side effects and required less opioid medication.
population_specificity: Individuals with hip fracture (N = 161) at three New York hospitals.
effective_dosage: Single-injection femoral nerve block followed by continuous fascia iliaca block within 24 hours.
study_duration: Intervention effects were measured up to 6 weeks after discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and clinical effects of a rapid up-titration dosing regimen of subcutaneous treprostinil with proactive infusion site pain management in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension.
results_summary: The study found that rapid up-titration of subcutaneous treprostinil was well tolerated, achieving a clinically effective dose associated with improved exercise capacity and hemodynamics after 16 weeks, though infusion site pain was common.
population_specificity: Patients with idiopathic or heritable pulmonary arterial hypertension on stable treatment with oral pulmonary arterial hypertension-approved drugs (90% on dual combination therapy).
effective_dosage: Median treprostinil dosage of 35.7 ng/kg/min after 16 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of moderate-intensity walking on lung function and respiratory muscle strength in dialysis patients.
results_summary: The study found that a minimal dose of structured walking improved physical capacity (measured by 6MWT) and maintained stable respiratory muscle function in dialysis patients, while the control group showed deterioration in respiratory muscle strength.
population_specificity: Dialysis patients (59 participants, 25 female, aged 65 ± 13 years).
effective_dosage: Two 10-minute walking sessions every second day at an intensity below the self-selected speed.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of exercise and/or nutritional supplementation on body composition, blood components, and physical function, including walking parameters, in elderly Japanese women with sarcopenic obesity.
results_summary: The study found that combined exercise and nutrition (Ex + N) significantly improved walking speed, stride, and vitamin D levels, while reducing body fat mass. Exercise alone (Ex) also reduced trunk fat, but no improvements in muscle mass or combined variables like percent fat + skeletal muscle mass index were observed.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling elderly Japanese women over 70 years of age with sarcopenic obesity.
effective_dosage: 60-minute exercise classes twice a week; daily essential amino acid supplementation and tea fortified with catechins.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of action observation training (AOT) on disease severity, freezing of gait, and motor abilities in Parkinson's disease patients, and to assess treatment-related brain functional changes.
results_summary: Both AOT and Landscape groups showed reduced freezing of gait severity, improved walking speed, and quality of life at 4 weeks. AOT demonstrated sustained improvements in motor disability, balance, and quality of life at 8 weeks, with associated functional brain changes in fronto-parietal areas.
population_specificity: 25 Parkinson's disease patients with freezing of gait.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of prolonged-release fampridine on physical and psychological health outcomes in individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS), beyond its known effects on walking impairment.
results_summary: PR-fampridine treatment resulted in significant improvements in both physical and psychological health outcomes compared to placebo, with sustained benefits over 24 weeks. A higher percentage of subjects showed improvements in most MSIS-29 physical and psychological items, particularly among those who also improved in walking ability.
population_specificity: Individuals with progressing or relapsing multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the efficacy and safety of oral nicorandil in coronary heart disease (CHD) patients with stable angina, not specifically evaluating Walking.
results_summary: The study found that nicorandil significantly reduced the number of ischemic attacks in CHD patients with stable angina but did not specifically evaluate the effects of Walking.
population_specificity: Adult patients with stable angina due to coronary heart disease.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on nicorandil, not Walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the immediate effects of perturbed treadmill walking on gait and balance in patients with Parkinson's disease compared to unperturbed treadmill walking.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant improvements in overground walking speed and reduced gait variability, while the control group exhibited increased postural sway. Patients with more pronounced motor impairment in the experimental group demonstrated larger improvements in walking speed and stance phase symmetry.
population_specificity: 39 Parkinson's disease patients in stages 1-3.5 of the Hoehn and Yahr Scale.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and synthesize evidence on the number of steps/day taken by individuals with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
results_summary: The study found that individuals with COPD had a pooled mean estimate of 4579 steps/day, indicating extremely low levels of physical activity. Severity of airflow obstruction (FEV) was associated with activity level.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) (2621 participants across 38 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel functional electrical stimulation (FES) setup for treating drop foot syndrome in stroke patients by improving foot pitch and roll angles during walking.
results_summary: The study found that the FES system, using a three-electrode setup and iterative learning control, achieved physiological foot pitch and roll angle trajectories within two strides, both on a treadmill and level ground. The approach effectively compensated for cross-couplings and adapted stimulation parameters to individual patient needs.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with drop foot syndrome

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of total knee replacement (TKR) followed by non-surgical treatment versus non-surgical treatment alone in reducing pain sensitization and other pain-related measures in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: TKR followed by non-surgical treatment was more effective in reducing localized and spreading pain sensitization compared to non-surgical treatment alone at 3 months, but both treatments were equally effective in reducing other pain-related measures.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether weight-bearing exercise like walking is safe and beneficial for people with diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN), challenging previous contraindications.
results_summary: The study found that weight-bearing activities, including walking, do not increase foot ulcer risk in DPN patients without severe foot deformity and may promote peripheral neuroplasticity and musculoskeletal adaptations. Emerging evidence supports a paradigm shift toward including such exercises for this population.
population_specificity: People with diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN) but without severe foot deformity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of an activity monitor versus a pedometer in exercise therapy for patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of walking, only that the study compared two monitoring devices.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the phenotypic spectrum, work-up, and treatment of gait disorders, focusing on their neurological and non-neurological causes.
results_summary: The study found that gait disorders are influenced by age, neurological conditions, and musculoskeletal issues, with prevalence increasing significantly in older adults. Safe walking requires intact cognition, and gait disorders can lead to reduced quality of life, falls, and injuries.
population_specificity: Older adults, particularly those aged 60 and above, with a focus on community-dwelling subjects over 80 years.
interactions: Adverse effects of medication, particularly polypharmacy including sedatives, were noted as potential contributors to gait disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of mHealth interventions in promoting physical activity (including walking) and reducing sedentary behavior compared to usual care/minimal intervention.
results_summary: The study found small, non-significant effects of mHealth interventions on walking (SMD 0.14, 95% CI -0.01 to 0.29), indicating minimal improvement compared to usual care.
population_specificity: Free-living young people and adults without conditions limiting physical activity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term outcomes of percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA), a supervised exercise programme (SEP), and combined treatment (PTA + SEP) in patients with intermittent claudication due to femoropopliteal disease.
results_summary: All treatments (PTA, SEP, and PTA + SEP) were equally effective long-term options for claudication. PTA and PTA + SEP showed higher ABPI than SEP alone, but no significant differences were observed in treadmill walking distances, QoL outcomes, or restenosis rates. The addition of SEP to PTA reduced symptomatic restenosis and reintervention rates.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication owing to femoropopliteal disease.
study_duration: Median follow-up of 5.2 years (interquartile range 3.8-7.4 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the "Walking Away from Type 2 Diabetes" intervention effectively increased and sustained walking activity in high-risk individuals when delivered in primary care.
results_summary: The intervention resulted in a modest increase of 411 steps/day at 12 months compared to control, but these differences were not sustained at 36 months. No significant improvements in cardiometabolic health markers were observed.
population_specificity: Individuals at high risk of Type 2 diabetes mellitus (36% female) identified through a validated risk score.
effective_dosage: A pragmatic 3-hour group-based structured education program with pedometer use and annual refresher sessions.
study_duration: 12 months (primary outcome), with follow-up at 24 and 36 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how power training affects leg muscle power and gait biomechanics in older adults with moderate mobility disability, ultimately leading to improved walking speed.
results_summary: The study expects power training to increase leg muscle power, which will translate to improved joint powers during gait, increased step length, and faster walking speed. The effects of training and detraining on these outcomes were measured over 10-week periods.
population_specificity: Older adults with moderate mobility disability
study_duration: 10 weeks of training, followed by 10 weeks of detraining

study_goal: To determine the feasibility of a trial of Nordic walking as an exercise intervention for women with aromatase inhibitor-associated arthralgia (AIAA).
results_summary: The study found that Nordic walking was feasible, with high adherence (>90% for supervised sessions, >80% for independent sessions), increased overall activity levels, and reduced pain in both intervention and control groups, with no adverse effects.
population_specificity: Women with aromatase inhibitor-associated arthralgia (AIAA) due to breast cancer treatment.
effective_dosage: Six-week supervised group Nordic walking once per week, followed by six weeks of 4 × 30 minutes/week independent Nordic walking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether trunk muscles are impaired in Myotonic Dystrophy 1 (DM1) patients and if this impairment correlates with disease duration, walking capacity, mobility, balance, and CTG-repeats.
results_summary: The study found significant trunk muscle impairment in DM1 patients, which correlated with larger mutation size, reduced walking capacity, mobility, and balance. Trunk impairments appear relatively early in disease progression and may impact daily functioning and fall risk.
population_specificity: 38 adult DM1 outpatients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate gait characteristics in MS patients with no apparent walking impairment (EDSS 0-1.5) and determine if abnormalities were detectable by common clinical tests.
results_summary: MS patients with no apparent disability performed worse in the T25FWT and 2MWT than healthy controls, showing prolonged double support phase during self-selected walking and lower cadence and decreased step length during fast walking.
population_specificity: 64 MS patients with EDSS 0-1.5 and 47 age- and sex-matched healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence of pulmonary disease in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) and evaluate the impact of treating pulmonary disorders on walking capacity.
results_summary: The study found a high prevalence of known and unknown pulmonary disease in PAD patients, with obstructive sleep apnea syndrome (OSAS) being the most common. Treatment of pulmonary disease significantly improved maximal walking distance in the treated group.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) and lower limb claudication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of acupuncture in reducing dyspnea and improving health-related quality of life in patients with COPD.
results_summary: The real acupuncture group showed significantly better outcomes in 6-minute walking distance and health-related quality of life compared to the sham acupuncture group. The findings suggest acupuncture can be an effective adjunctive therapy for COPD patients.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical efficacy and complications of two surgical techniques (MKTB and CSTB) for treating transverse patellar fractures, including their impact on walking assistance and knee function.
results_summary: The CSTB group showed better clinical outcomes, including higher scores in ROM, pain, and effusion, compared to the MKTB group. Removing implants in the MKTB group improved knee function, but CSTB avoided issues like painful hardware and implant loosening.
population_specificity: 55 patients with transverse patellar fractures (29 in MKTB group, 26 in CSTB group).
study_duration: Not specified (follow-up until implant removal in MKTB group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the impact of a structured, individual sports program, including walking, on fatigue in patients with advanced cancer.
results_summary: The study found that mental fatigue showed a statistically significant difference between groups, with severe general fatigue significantly reduced in the group receiving additional physiotherapeutical supervision. Walking distance was a secondary outcome, but specific results for walking were not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced cancer (heterogeneous cohort with various cancer types).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether specifying the timing of walking in relation to meals enhances the glycemic benefits of physical activity for individuals with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Walking for 10 minutes after each main meal significantly reduced postprandial glycemia compared to walking 30 minutes at any time of day, with the most pronounced effect after the evening meal. The improvement was measured by a lower incremental area under the blood glucose curve (iAUC).
population_specificity: 41 adults with type 2 diabetes (mean age 60 ± 9.9 years, mean diabetes duration 10 years).
effective_dosage: 10 minutes after each main meal (3 times daily) or 30 minutes at any time of day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of treadmill belt speed on balance control during walking, measured by inclination angles and the rate of change of the center of mass relative to the center of pressure.
results_summary: The study found that preferred walking speed (PWS) provided the best compromise between frontal stability during single-limb support and smooth weight-transfer during double-limb support. Most variables showed linear trends with increasing speed, with PWS exhibiting the smallest range of frontal inclination angles during single-limb support.
population_specificity: Twelve healthy adults
effective_dosage: Five belt speeds, including subjects' preferred walking speed

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term effects of a hospital-based pulmonary rehabilitation program coupled with negative pressure ventilation (NPV) and unsupervised daily walking on clinical outcomes in COPD patients.
results_summary: The study found that the NPV group, which included daily walking, showed significant improvements in 6-minute walk test distance over 4 years, reduced emergency room visits and hospitalizations, and lower annual medical costs compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) (n=129).
effective_dosage: 20 to 30 minutes of daily unsupervised walking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of the BEAT Cancer intervention on social cognitive theory constructs and their mediating role in increasing physical activity among breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: The BEAT Cancer intervention significantly improved self-efficacy, goals, negative outcome expectations, and barriers, but no significant indirect effects on physical activity improvements were observed 3 months post-intervention.
population_specificity: Post-treatment breast cancer survivors (N = 222)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the burden of osteoporotic hip fractures, including health resource utilization, quality of life, and autonomy, over the first year post-fracture.
results_summary: The study found high societal and economic costs associated with osteoporotic hip fractures, primarily due to initial hospitalization, outpatient visits, and home care. Quality of life and autonomy significantly decreased during hospitalization and did not fully recover by 12 months.
population_specificity: Patients aged ≥65 years hospitalized due to a first low-trauma hip fracture in six Spanish regions (mean age 83 ± 7 years, 77% women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of two school-based physical activity programs, including a walking/running program (100 Mile Club®), on children's moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA), cognitive function, and academic outcomes.
results_summary: The study assessed the effects of the 100 Mile Club® walking/running program on MVPA, cognitive function, and academic achievement, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract. The trial design suggests a focus on measuring short- and long-term impacts through accelerometry, cognitive assessments, and standardized test scores.
population_specificity: Low-income, ethnically diverse elementary schoolchildren (grades 3-4) in Massachusetts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a graduated walking program on fatigue in individuals with traumatic brain injury (TBI).
results_summary: The walking intervention led to reduced fatigue as measured by multiple fatigue scales (GFI, BNI, MFI), with improvements sustained after the intervention and a washout period. Step counts increased over time regardless of group assignment.
population_specificity: 123 individuals over age 18 with traumatic brain injury (TBI).
effective_dosage: Home-based walking program with pedometer tracking and incremental step increases, accompanied by tapered coaching calls.
study_duration: 12-week intervention, with follow-up at 24 and 36 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 6-week supervised exercise program could improve gait patterns, pain, and physical function in patients with bilateral medial knee osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in knee abductor moment (KAM), lever arm, or ground reaction force, but observed improved pain, physical function, and altered gait patterns (higher hip flexor moment, hip extension angle, and faster walking speed) in patients with knee OA after the exercise intervention.
population_specificity: Six female patients with bilateral medial knee OA and six healthy controls.
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise program included non-weight-bearing strengthening without external resistance and stretching).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining lower limb revascularization with supervised exercise training improves functional outcomes and quality of life in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) compared to either treatment alone.
results_summary: Combined therapy led to greater improvements in pain-free and maximal walking distances compared to revascularization or supervised exercise alone. It also showed superior effects on leg blood flow and physical quality of life domains compared to exercise alone, with similar benefits to revascularization alone for hemodynamics and mental quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease (mean age 66 ± 3 years, ABI 0.66 ± 0.05).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to outline a diagnostic approach for identifying functional or psychogenic gait disorders by categorizing them into four overlapping syndromes.
results_summary: The study suggests a stepwise analysis to diagnose psychogenic gait disorders, dividing them into movement disorder mimics, neurologic mimics, musculoskeletal mimics, and isolated balance disorders, with accurate diagnosis leading to effective therapy.
population_specificity: Individuals with functional neurologic disorders presenting with gait disturbances.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of scalp acupuncture combined with electromagnetic convergence stimulation (SAEM-CS) against conventional stroke rehabilitation, scalp acupuncture (SA), and repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) in improving function, including walking, in patients with cerebral infarction.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding walking; it mentions walking as a secondary outcome measure but does not detail findings.
population_specificity: Patients with motion or sensory disabilities caused by a first-time cerebral infarction within 1 month of study onset (n=60).
effective_dosage: SA, rTMS, and SAEM-CS treatments were administered once/day, 5 days/week for 3 weeks (total 15 sessions).
study_duration: 3 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 4 weeks post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine contamination (aerobic activity outside of exercise sessions) in a randomized exercise trial, comparing Walking to Dance and Strength/Stretching/Stability (SSS) conditions.
results_summary: The Walking group showed the lowest out-of-class aerobic activity, suggesting participants may have perceived exercise sessions as sufficient weekly exercise. Higher perceived enjoyment was associated with more out-of-class activity, while higher perceived intensity was linked to less out-of-class activity.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age = 65.06 years, 66.2% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects of multi-channel functional electrical stimulation (MFES)-assisted gait training on restoring spatiotemporal gait symmetry and walking capacity in subacute stroke patients.
results_summary: The study is a proof-of-principle trial with a randomized controlled design, assessing MFES-assisted gait training versus conventional gait training. Results will inform the feasibility and effectiveness of MFES in early stroke rehabilitation, but specific outcomes are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adult stroke patients with walking deficits admitted for inpatient rehabilitation within 31 days of stroke onset.
effective_dosage: 30-minute sessions each workday for up to 10 weeks.

study_goal: To investigate whether action observation training involving community-based ambulation improves walking ability in post-stroke hemiparesis patients.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant improvements in walking function, including speed, community walk test performance, balance confidence, and spatiotemporal gait parameters, compared to the control group. The control group only showed improvement in the 10-m walk test.
population_specificity: 25 inpatients with post-stroke hemiparesis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the Cardioband system for reducing functional mitral regurgitation (FMR) and improving heart failure symptoms, including exercise capacity measured by a 6-minute walking test.
results_summary: The study found that the Cardioband system significantly reduced mitral regurgitation, improved heart failure symptoms, and increased exercise capacity (measured by walking distance) from 250 ± 107 m to 332 ± 118 m after 7 months. Quality of life also improved significantly.
population_specificity: Symptomatic patients with moderate to severe FMR, heart failure, and depressed left ventricular function (average age 71.8 ± 6.9 years, 83.9% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare single-task and dual-task gait performance between collision/contact and noncontact athletes to determine if preexisting gait differences exist.
results_summary: No significant gait differences were found between collision/contact and noncontact athletes during single-task or dual-task conditions. Noncontact athletes showed higher cognitive task accuracy during single-task standing and dual-task gait than collision/contact athletes.
population_specificity: Collegiate athletes (n = 265, mean age = 19.1 ± 1.1 years) from three institutions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the effect of Multiple Sclerosis (MS) on gait variables to inform falls prevention interventions.
results_summary: The study found a large effect of MS on stride length, velocity, double support duration, step length, and swing phase duration, with moderate effects on step width and stride time, and the smallest effect on cadence. These effects were amplified under fast walking conditions.
population_specificity: People with Multiple Sclerosis (EDSS 1.8 to 4.5) compared to healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of interval length (3 min vs. 1 min) on postprandial glycemic control following interval walking in individuals with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Interval walking (both 3 min and 1 min cycles) lowered postprandial blood glucose levels compared to no walking, with no significant difference between the two interval lengths. Specific time points during the meal tolerance test showed significant glucose reductions after both interval walking protocols.
population_specificity: Twelve subjects with type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: 1-hour interventions with repeated cycles of slow (54% VO2peak) and fast (89% VO2peak) walking, either 3 min/3 min (IW3) or 1 min/1 min (IW1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of supervised exercise training, including walking, in improving functional capacity, quality of life, and reducing intermittent claudication in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: Supervised exercise programs significantly improved functional capacity and quality of life while reducing intermittent claudication. These programs were also found to reduce morbidity and mortality and were deemed cost-effective, though underutilized.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD), particularly those experiencing intermittent claudication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in the 6-minute walk test distance relative to functional capacity measures after 16 weeks of exercise training in older HFpEF patients.
results_summary: Both the exercise training and attention control groups showed increased 6-MWT distance (11% and 9%, respectively), but peak oxygen uptake improved only in the exercise training group. The study questions the validity of the 6-MWT as a serial measure of exercise tolerance in this population.
population_specificity: Older patients (≥65 years) with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).
effective_dosage: Walking at 50% to 70% of peak oxygen uptake (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze risk factors for mortality and medical/orthopaedic complications in hip fracture patients, including the impact of surgical delay and other variables.
results_summary: The study found that surgical delay longer than 24 hours increased wound infection risk (OR=3.48), older age was a significant risk factor for mortality and pneumonia, and previous comorbidity increased risks for cardiac failure and pneumonia. After one year, 6% of previously walking patients were unable to walk.
population_specificity: 697 hip fracture patients (average age 85±9 years, 75% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether plantar mechanical stimulation could modulate autonomic nervous system activity and impact blood pressure adaptation during standing.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in orthostatic tolerance time, stroke volume, or cardiac baroreflex sensitivity between the different plantar stimulation modes. Plantar mechanical stimulation did not effectively modulate cardiac sympathetic or parasympathetic activity under orthostatic stress.
population_specificity: Twelve healthy subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of aerobic training (AT) versus resistance training (RT) on gait speed and other functional measures in overweight and obese older adults.
results_summary: Both AT and RT improved usual-pace gait speed and functional measures, but only AT improved fast-pace gait speed. Lower baseline fitness was associated with less improvement in training outcomes.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese older adults (BMI ≥27.0 kg/m², aged 65+).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore perceptions of group-based walking and gather suggestions to inform the development of a walking intervention among older adults in retirement villages.
results_summary: The study identified key themes influencing participation, such as motivation, fears, and environmental factors, and proposed intervention strategies like trained walk leaders and flexible planning to enhance appeal and feasibility. Group-based walking programs were suggested as a potential method to promote physical activity among older adults.
population_specificity: Physically inactive older adults (69-88 years) and managers from retirement villages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a home-based exercise program on physical function, physical activity, quality of life, and self-efficacy in chronically ill, mobility-limited elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between the experimental and control groups in functional lower body strength, physical function, physical activity, quality of life, or self-efficacy measures, concluding the program was ineffective for the target population.
population_specificity: Chronically ill and mobility-limited individuals aged 70 and older (mean age 80 ± 5, 74% female, 87% with three or more chronic diseases, 54% using a walking aid).
effective_dosage: Not specified (12-week multidimensional home-based exercise program with behavioral strategies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate intervention strategies for restoring walking ability in individuals with spinal cord injury, focusing on targeting neural elements at multiple levels of the neuraxis.
results_summary: The study found that physical therapeutic rehabilitation strategies remain more effective than pharmacological, biological, or genetic approaches for restoring walking ability. It also highlighted the importance of volitional lower extremity strength and supraspinal centers in predicting walking function and responsiveness to training.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether progressive treadmill walking exercise training improves cognition, walking performance, and cardiorespiratory fitness in fully ambulatory persons with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found large intervention effects on cognitive processing speed, walking performance, and cardiorespiratory fitness, with improved fitness potentially linked to better cognitive processing speed.
population_specificity: Fully ambulatory females with multiple sclerosis (MS).
effective_dosage: 12 weeks of supervised, progressive treadmill walking exercise training (specific frequency and intensity not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prevalence of exercise-induced oxygen desaturation (EID) in COPD patients and its relationship with physiological determinants and clinical characteristics.
results_summary: The study analyzed data from 2050 COPD patients but did not report specific findings on walking's effects in the provided abstract.
population_specificity: 2050 COPD patients (age: 63.3 ± 7.1 years).

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine the effects of experience on the MitraClip procedure, including procedural duration, safety, and functional outcomes, but the abstract does not focus on walking as a primary intervention.
results_summary: The study found that procedural duration and safety improved with experience, and baseline 6-minute walking test results improved from group I to group III, but the abstract does not detail walking-specific outcomes.
population_specificity: 126 consecutive patients with mitral regurgitation, predominantly in NYHA-stage ≥III and with low LVEF.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a long-term home-based exercise program, including moderate-intensity walking, could improve blood pressure, metabolic profile, and physical fitness in low-income hypertensive patients.
results_summary: The study found that the home-based walking program significantly improved body composition, aerobic efficiency, flexibility, blood lipid profiles, and blood pressure compared to the control group. Benefits were sustained over 16 months, with systolic and diastolic blood pressure reductions stabilizing after six months.
population_specificity: Low-income Brazilian patients diagnosed with hypertension (29 in the exercise group, 14 in the control group).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of moderate-intensity walking plus stretching exercises (frequency not specified).
