study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of medical electronic devices (IPC, NMES, EMS) in managing peripheral arterial disease (PAD) symptoms, including walking capacity and circulatory enhancement.
results_summary: IPC devices significantly improved popliteal artery velocity, flow, walking distance (ICD and AWD), and quality of life in PAD patients. EMS and NMES also showed benefits in increasing blood flow and walking distance, though evidence for CLI management was lacking.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD), including those with intermittent claudication and critical limb ischemia (CLI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of standard treadmill-based supervised exercise on skeletal muscle mass (SMM) and regional lower limb lean mass (LM) in patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: The study found no loss of calf LM but a significant decrease in bilateral thigh LM after 12 weeks of treadmill training. Walking performance (pain-free walking distance and 6-minute walking distance) improved significantly, but these improvements were not associated with changes in LM.
population_specificity: Patients with calf claudication caused by infrainguinal peripheral artery disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the cerebral mechanisms underlying freezing of gait (FOG) in Parkinson's disease, focusing on brain physiology, animal models, and potential treatments like PPN stimulation.
results_summary: The study identified a dynamic network of cortical and subcortical areas involved in gait control, including the supplementary motor area, striatum, and mesencephalic locomotor region, and reviewed PPN stimulation as a potential treatment for FOG.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease experiencing freezing of gait (FOG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in aerobic exercise performance in participants with subacute stroke following high-intensity variable stepping training compared to conventional therapy.
results_summary: Significant improvements were observed in submaximal oxygen consumption, with less consistent improvements in oxygen cost. Combined changes in both submaximal oxygen consumption and oxygen cost at matched peak baseline speeds correlated better with walking function improvements than either measure alone.
population_specificity: Individuals 1 to 6 months post-stroke.
effective_dosage: 40 or fewer sessions of high-intensity variable stepping training.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but assessments were done at baseline, post-training, and 2- to 3-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe piriformis syndrome in a Bangladeshi population and review associated literature, noting incidental observations about pain improvement while walking.
results_summary: Six patients reported pain improvement while walking, but the study primarily focused on diagnosing piriformis syndrome rather than evaluating walking as an intervention.
population_specificity: 31 piriformis syndrome patients (21 female, 21 housewives) in Bangladesh, mean age 42.2 ± 14.5 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and rehabilitation on gait characteristics and clinical scores in patients compared to healthy controls.
results_summary: Clinical knee and function scores improved significantly post-surgery. Gait parameters like single support time and foot fall showed significant differences between patients and healthy controls, with some improvements over time. Single support time on the diseased side correlated with clinical scores, suggesting it as a sensitive measure for TKA outcomes.
population_specificity: 12 patients undergoing TKA and 12 healthy controls.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical intervention, not a supplement).
study_duration: Evaluated before surgery, 6 weeks, and 6 months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the symptoms, diagnosis, subtypes, etiology, and treatment options for bilateral vestibulopathy (BVP), particularly focusing on its impact on gait and balance.
results_summary: The study found that BVP causes postural imbalance and unsteady gait, worsens in darkness or on uneven ground, and may include movement-induced oscillopsia. Diagnosis involves assessing vestibulo-ocular reflex function, and treatment includes patient counseling, vestibular exercises, addressing underlying causes, and preventive measures.
population_specificity: Patients with bilateral vestibulopathy (BVP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a low-intensity, community-based exercise program (including walking) yielded better mobility benefits than a high-intensity program in chronic stroke survivors.
results_summary: The low-intensity program (LI-E) showed greater improvement in mobility (6MWD), quality of life (SF36 physical activity domain), and muscle power (quadriceps and biceps) compared to the high-intensity program (HI-C). Both groups improved in gait speed, balance, and lower-limb strength, but no significant differences were noted between them.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke survivors (mean age 68.4±10.4 years, 27 males).
effective_dosage: Low-intensity group: over-ground intermittent walking (weeks 1-8) and muscle power training (weeks 5-8); High-intensity group: treadmill walking (weeks 1-8) and strength training (weeks 5-8).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of oral THC on mobility in dementia patients, particularly regarding the risk of falling.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of THC on mobility or falling risk in dementia patients.
population_specificity: Eighteen community-dwelling dementia patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a community-based exercise intervention to improve gait parameters and functional fitness in older populations.
results_summary: The study proposed a controlled trial to evaluate the effects of the intervention on plantar pressure gait parameters, aerobic endurance, lower limb strength, agility, and balance, with measurements taken at baseline and after 12, 24, and 36 weeks. The abstract suggests potential effectiveness but does not report specific results.
population_specificity: Older populations

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility of a video-game exercise program for older people with chronic low back pain, focusing on study processes and secondary outcomes like pain, physical function, and walking speed.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results on walking effects, but the study measured secondary outcomes including walking speed, pain, and physical function, with results to inform future RCT design.
population_specificity: Older adults (over 55 years) with chronic low back pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether physical activity consultation and pram walking groups could increase physical activity and improve health outcomes (weight, body composition, well-being, fatigue) among inactive postnatal women.
results_summary: The intervention showed no significant effect on weight, body composition, or general well-being at three or six months. There was a significant but inconsistent difference in fatigue between groups, and qualitative data suggested perceived benefits not supported by objective findings.
population_specificity: Inactive postnatal women
study_duration: Follow-up at three and six months

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical relevance of compression pressures during walking and the importance of the Static Stiffness Index (SSI) in improving venous pumping function.
results_summary: The study found that compression pressures during walking are more clinically relevant than resting pressures, and the SSI is a valuable parameter for assessing compression therapy efficacy in narrowing/occluding the venous lumen, reducing venous reflux, and improving venous pumping function.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of compression therapy principles).
effective_dosage: Not specified (discusses compression pressures but no specific dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of telephone health-mentoring for home-based walking (tele-rehab) compared to usual care in improving physical capacity and other outcomes in people with COPD.
results_summary: The study found no significant benefit of telephone-mentoring for home-based walking on exercise capacity (6MWD) or secondary outcomes. Supervised exercise showed a nonsignificant improvement in 6MWD, suggesting it may be essential in pulmonary rehabilitation.
population_specificity: People with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
study_duration: 8-12 weeks for tele-rehab, followed by 8 weeks of group pulmonary rehabilitation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical and radiological outcomes of two surgical approaches (sinus tarsi and extended lateral) for treating displaced intraarticular calcaneal fractures.
results_summary: The sinus tarsi approach resulted in significantly fewer wound complications and shorter preoperative waiting time compared to the extended lateral approach, while achieving similar functional and radiological outcomes. No significant differences were found in walking visual analogue scale or American Orthopedic Foot & Ankle Society scores between the two groups at 6 months and 1 year postoperatively.
population_specificity: Patients with displaced intraarticular calcaneal fractures.
study_duration: Follow-up at 6 months and 1 year postoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a smartphone-based secondary prevention program emphasizing early physical activity (graduated walking) could improve exercise capacity and cardiovascular health in patients with acute coronary syndromes (ACS).
results_summary: The study assessed changes in exercise capacity (via six-minute walk test) and secondary outcomes like cardiovascular risk factors, psychological well-being, and medication adherence, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract. The trial aimed to evaluate the feasibility and utility of the smartphone-based intervention.
population_specificity: Patients recently discharged after acute coronary syndromes (ACS).
effective_dosage: Graduated walking program (specific frequency/distance not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the test-retest reliability, validity, and responsiveness to change of the 30-meter walking test (30MWT) in patients with degenerative cervical myelopathy (DCM).
results_summary: The 30MWT demonstrated high test-retest reliability and good convergent and divergent validity but was only responsive to change in patients with more severe myelopathy. The test is simple, quick, and affordable, suitable as an ancillary gait evaluation tool for DCM patients.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic degenerative cervical myelopathy (DCM) enrolled in multicenter studies.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walking test, not a supplement).
study_duration: Evaluated at baseline and 6 months postoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different ankle foot orthoses affect gastrocnemius operating length during walking in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found that ankle foot orthoses could stretch the gastrocnemius more than barefoot walking for some individuals, though results varied between participants and orthosis types. Orthoses also reduced peak gastrocnemius lengthening velocity, particularly in participants with more severe motor impairments.
population_specificity: 11 children with cerebral palsy (Gross Motor Functional Classification System Level I and III).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the clinical characteristics, treatments, and outcomes of exercise-induced vasculitis (EIV) following prolonged physical activities like walking, particularly in hot weather.
results_summary: The study found that EIV, presenting as erythematous or purpuric plaques on the lower legs, resolves spontaneously within 10 days but has frequent relapses (77.5%) if triggering conditions persist. Histopathology confirmed leukocytoclastic vasculitis in most cases, with venous stasis and thermoregulation decompensation as likely causes.
population_specificity: 99 patients (including 16 treated at the authors' hospital from 2007–2015) who developed EIV after activities like walking, dancing, swimming, or hiking in hot weather.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the musical characteristics preferred by older adults with cardiac disease during walking-based exercise and explore their experiences with music listening post-cardiac rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found that preferred music for walking had specific characteristics like duple meter and major key, and participants reported psycho-emotional and physical benefits. Music also influenced exercise behavior, though some negative experiences were noted.
population_specificity: Older adults (60+ years) with cardiac disease (21 men, 6 women; mean age 67.3 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a resistance exercise program versus walking on lipid profile and chylomicron concentration in older men.
results_summary: The walking group (active control) showed no significant changes in lipid profile, glycaemic control, or anthropometric measures compared to the resistance exercise group, which had improvements in LDL-cholesterol and lean body mass.
population_specificity: Older men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a visual-acoustic alarm activated by movement discrepancy could enhance the use of the neglect arm during bimanual tasks, including walking, in stroke patients with hemineglect.
results_summary: The study found that the neglect hand's motion and function improved during the 7-day training with alarms, but the improvement was limited to vision-dependent tasks and did not persist after the alarms were turned off.
population_specificity: 9 stroke patients with residual hemineglect of the arm

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a physical activity intervention (walking, resistance training, and flexibility exercises) improved physical and cognitive function in older, sedentary adults with and without type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The physical activity intervention improved gait speed in both individuals with and without diabetes, but cognitive benefits were only observed in those with diabetes, particularly in global cognitive function and delayed memory. No benefits were seen on physical performance battery scores.
population_specificity: Sedentary, non-demented adults aged 70-89 years with functional limitations, including 415 individuals with diabetes and 1,061 without diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term efficacy, safety, and pharmacokinetics of drisapersen in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) patients with amenable mutations.
results_summary: The study found that drisapersen was generally well tolerated over 188 weeks, with improvements in six-minute walk distance (6MWD) sustained for most patients. However, some adverse events like injection-site reactions and possible renal effects were noted.
population_specificity: 12 DMD subjects with amenable mutations, mean age 9.5 years.
effective_dosage: 6 mg/kg subcutaneously, once weekly for 72 weeks, followed by intermittent dosing.

study_goal: To determine if constraining treadmill walking to the sagittal plane improves swing-phase hip and knee flexion in individuals with chronic stroke.
results_summary: Constraining treadmill walking significantly improved hip and knee flexion during initial and midswing, with moderate-to-large effect sizes. Immediate changes in step width and paretic step length were also observed.
population_specificity: Eight individuals (mean age 64.1, 2 female) with mild-moderate paresis due to chronic stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of an implanted functional electrical stimulation system on walking patterns in stroke patients with drop foot.
results_summary: The study found that the stimulation improved walking speed by 45%, stride length by 22%, and dorsiflexion angles, while also reducing pathologic gait elements like knee hyperextension and leg circumduction. Younger subjects showed more significant improvements.
population_specificity: Four stroke patients with drop foot, varying in age and time since surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of 12 weeks of strength training and aerobic training versus standard care on physical fitness, mobility, and quality of life in patients with mild to moderate Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: Strength training improved peak torque measures, peak work load, and walking capacity, while aerobic training improved peak oxygen consumption and peak work load. However, neither intervention significantly improved gait or health-related quality of life.
population_specificity: Fifty-two outpatients with mild to moderate Parkinson's disease.
effective_dosage: Not specified (individualized strength training and tailored aerobic cycling).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of preemptive analgesia on inflammatory response and rehabilitation, including walking capacity, in patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: Preemptive analgesia reduced pain at rest and during walking, lowered hs-CRP levels, and improved 2-minute walk test (2MWT) performance in the first week postoperatively, but did not significantly affect long-term function or 6-minute walk test (6MWT) and WOMAC scores between groups.
population_specificity: 75 patients with unilateral primary knee osteoarthritis undergoing TKA.
study_duration: First week postoperatively (specific intervention duration not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the reliability, validity, and interpretability of four clinical measures for assessing balance dysfunction in individuals with cerebellar ataxia secondary to multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The study found that all four balance assessment measures demonstrated good reliability and acceptable validity, with the Berg Balance Scale and specific subcomponents of the SARA being recommended for clinical use due to their superior performance. The measures could discriminate between assistive walking device users and nonusers, though correlations with disease severity and functional independence were moderate to poor.
population_specificity: Individuals with cerebellar ataxia secondary to multiple sclerosis (N=60).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity treadmill training (HITT) versus low-intensity treadmill training (LITT) on gait ability, quality of life, cardiorespiratory fitness, and walking energy cost in chronic stroke survivors.
results_summary: HITT significantly improved gait ability (Six-Minute Walk Test, Ten-Meter Walk Test), spatio-temporal gait parameters, VO2peak, and reduced walking energy cost compared to LITT, which showed no significant improvements.
population_specificity: 16 chronic stroke survivors (15 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dual-task interference on upright gait stability during walking across different population groups.
results_summary: All subjects showed reduced walking speed during dual-task conditions, with significant differences among groups. Trunk acceleration measurements indicated changes in stability along different axes during dual-task walking, particularly in subjects with cerebral palsy and stroke.
population_specificity: Healthy young, healthy elderly, children with typical development, children with cerebral palsy, and adults with stroke in subacute phase.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a new clinical test (AVA) to measure peripheral target detection in individuals with tunnel vision, assessing its correlation with mobility performance.
results_summary: The AVA test was sensitive to field of view and target location, showing significant correlations with walking speed and collision avoidance in simulated tunnel vision, but not in actual patients with retinitis pigmentosa. The test was repeatable and valid for assessing mobility-related visual awareness.
population_specificity: 20 patients with tunnel vision due to retinitis pigmentosa and 50 normally sighted participants with simulated tunnel vision.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare mental imagery of gait and spatiotemporal gait parameters in dementia patients before and after using anti-dementia drugs versus controls.
results_summary: The study found that anti-dementia drugs improved mental imagery of gait (longer iTUG time and lower delta-TUG value) but did not affect actual gait performance. The intervention group showed significant changes in these metrics compared to controls.
population_specificity: 112 patients (mean age 82.5 ± 4.2 years, 68.8% female) with mild-to-moderate Alzheimer's disease and non-AD dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate variability in functional responses to walking and physical activity interventions in older adults with limited mobility and identify factors contributing to these changes.
results_summary: Greater baseline physical function was negatively associated with improvements in gait speed and lower extremity function, while higher daily step count, younger age, lower BMI, and higher self-reported physical activity were positively associated with improvements.
population_specificity: Sedentary men and women aged 70-89 years with physical limitations (SPPB score ≤9) who could walk 400m.
effective_dosage: Moderate-intensity physical activity (aerobic, resistance, flexibility exercises) 2 times/week center-based and 3-4 times/week home-based.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review advancements in medical exoskeletons for restoring upright walking in individuals with central nervous system injuries.
results_summary: The study highlights the limitations of current mobility aids (braces, wheelchairs, functional electrical stimulation) and identifies medical exoskeletons as a promising solution for improving walking function in impaired individuals. It summarizes key features, limitations, and clinical applicability of available or emerging exoskeleton technologies.
population_specificity: Individuals with central nervous system injuries and mobility impairments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether Focal Vibrations (FV) are effective in improving walking impairment in patients with Multiple Sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: Treated patients showed significant improvements in gait parameters (e.g., stride length, double support time) and functional scales (e.g., BBS, FSS), while the sham group showed no significant changes. The benefits partially persisted at follow-up.
population_specificity: 20 patients with Relapsing-Remitting Multiple Sclerosis (RR MS).
study_duration: Treatment duration not explicitly stated, but assessments were done at baseline (T0), post-treatment (T1), and after a three-week washout (T2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of treadmill-based C-Mill therapy and overground FALLS program on walking speed and adaptability in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that C-Mill therapy would yield better outcomes due to greater walking practice, but results were not provided in the abstract. Secondary measures included walking adaptability, balance, and independence assessments.
population_specificity: Forty persons ≥3 months post-stroke with walking or balance deficits.
effective_dosage: Not specified (interventions matched in frequency, duration, and therapist attention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether providing monitored activity data to patients and clinicians, combined with explicit goal setting, could increase walking times in older rehabilitation inpatients.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a significant increase in daily walking time (from 10.3 to 32.1 minutes) compared to the control group (from 9.5 to 26.5 minutes), with a mean difference of 7 minutes in non-therapy walking time (p = 0.001). Objective monitoring and feedback improved mobility-related activity levels during rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Inpatients aged 60 and older in rehabilitation with a goal to become ambulant.
effective_dosage: Not specified (monitored walking time data provided daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if immune modulation therapy (including thymopentin) could improve cardiac function and regulate cytokines and lymphocyte subsets in older patients with chronic heart failure (CHF).
results_summary: The study found that immune modulation therapy improved cardiac function (increased LVEF, 6MWT, CD3+, CD4+T cells, natural killer cells, CD4+/CD8+ ratio, and IL-10) and reduced inflammatory markers (BNP, hsCRP, TNF-α, IL-1ß, and TNF-α/IL-10 ratio) in older CHF patients.
population_specificity: Older patients (60+ years) with chronic heart failure (CHF).
effective_dosage: 2 mg thymopentin per day, administered in 15-day courses (three courses total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of functional electrical stimulation (FES) and ankle foot orthoses on walking behaviors in individuals with foot-drop caused by stroke.
results_summary: The study found that both FES and ankle foot orthoses had comparable positive effects on walking speed, functional exercise capacity, timed up-and-go, and perceived mobility in stroke patients with foot-drop. However, further long-term, high-quality RCTs are needed to confirm these findings and explore mechanisms of action.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with foot-drop of central neurological origin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how interruptions to prolonged sitting with light- or moderate-intensity walking affect glucose metabolism and skeletal muscle mechanisms in overweight adults.
results_summary: The study found that both acute and repeated interruptions to sitting with walking reduced postprandial glucose levels, stimulated glucose uptake pathways, and improved insulin signaling, with moderate-intensity walking also enhancing glycogen synthesis and ATP production capacity.
population_specificity: Overweight adults (n=8 for one-day interventions, n=5 for three-day interventions).
effective_dosage: Light- or moderate-intensity walking every 20 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether calf-muscle electro-stimulation improves claudication distance in individuals with type 2 diabetes and peripheral artery disease.
results_summary: The study found a significant mean increase of 137 meters in absolute claudication distance after 12 weeks of electrical stimulation, indicating improved maximal walking capacity. The results were statistically significant (p = 0.000).
population_specificity: 40 participants with type 2 diabetes, peripheral artery disease (ankle-brachial pressure index < 0.90), and calf-muscle claudication (30 males, mean age 71 years).
effective_dosage: Calf-muscle electro-stimulation of varying frequencies (1-250 Hz) for 1 hour per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the Astron stent for treating atherosclerotic lesions in iliac arteries, focusing on major adverse event rates and quality of life improvements.
results_summary: The study found a low MAE rate (2.1%) at 12 months, high primary patency (89.8%), and significant improvements in walking ability and quality of life measures (WIQ scores).
population_specificity: 161 patients with symptomatic iliac lesions in the US, Canada, and Austria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the presence or absence of bone marrow lesions (BMLs) in knee osteoarthritis (OA) patients influenced treatment outcomes from walking or strength exercises.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in pain scores or global perceived effect between knee OA patients with and without BMLs after 18 weeks of walking or strength exercises. Both interventions were effective in improving pain, but BMLs did not predict treatment outcomes.
population_specificity: Symptomatic knee osteoarthritis patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare patient satisfaction levels between in-home telerehabilitation and standard face-to-face rehabilitation after total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and assess associations with functional outcomes like walking performance.
results_summary: Both telerehabilitation and standard rehabilitation groups reported very high satisfaction (over 85%), with satisfaction linked to walking and stair-climbing performance rather than personal characteristics or functional improvements.
population_specificity: 205 patients who underwent total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
study_duration: Assessed at baseline, hospital discharge, and 2 and 4 months post-discharge.

study_goal: To assess the efficacy and safety of short and long-term exercise (including walking) prior to influenza vaccination in enhancing influenza prevention in adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in influenza outcomes between those who exercised (including walking) and those who did not before vaccination. Limited and low-quality evidence suggested no benefit or harm from pre-vaccination exercise.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-80 years (gender proportions not fully reported).
effective_dosage: One session of 25-50 minutes (five studies) or eight weeks of exercise including daily 45-minute sessions (one study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of tramadol hydrochloride/acetaminophen (TRAM/APAP) with NSAIDs for perioperative pain management and rehabilitation progress after total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: TRAM/APAP significantly improved pain VAS scores compared to NSAIDs and enabled faster achievement of cane-walking independence. The study concluded TRAM/APAP was superior for perioperative pain management and rehabilitation after TKA.
population_specificity: 280 patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty (TKA), divided into TRAM/APAP (137) and NSAID (143) groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate gender differences in foot self-care and lifestyle habits, including walking barefoot, among individuals with diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The study found that men had a higher prevalence of foot self-care deficits, such as walking barefoot, but lower prevalence of other risk factors like inappropriate shoe use compared to women. Men also exhibited less healthy lifestyle habits overall.
population_specificity: 1,515 individuals with diabetes mellitus aged 40 years or older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a standard group exercise program and the "On the Move" program on function, disability, and mobility in older adults.
results_summary: The study assessed function, disability, and mobility using validated instruments but did not report specific numerical outcomes in the abstract. Stakeholder involvement improved the relevance and adoption of the exercise program.
population_specificity: Older adults residing in independent living facilities, senior apartment buildings, and attending community centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the hemodynamic characteristics and efficacy of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) therapies in patients with bronchiectasis and PH, including the impact on 6-minute walking distance.
results_summary: The study found that PH with severe hemodynamic impairment occurs in patients with bilateral bronchiectasis, and PAH therapy improved hemodynamics, reducing systolic PAP after 6 months. The 6-minute walking distance was 300.8 ± 3.3 m, and survival rates were 97.1% at 1 year, 83.4% at 3 years, and 64.5% at 5 years.
population_specificity: 36 patients with bilateral bronchiectasis and concurrent PH (mean age 51.5 years, range 17–74).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of open reduction surgery without osteotomy in treating hip dislocation diagnosed after walking age and to identify predictors of acetabular development.
results_summary: The study found that open reduction improved acetabular index and center-edge angle over time, with the center-edge angle at one year post-surgery serving as a significant predictor of long-term acetabular development. The capital femoral ossific nucleus diameter normalized within 6-12 months after surgery.
population_specificity: 38 children (43 hips) diagnosed with complete hip dislocation after walking age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the health benefits of walking and Tai Chi, focusing on aerobic fitness, energy expenditure, body composition, and quality of life.
results_summary: Walking significantly improved VO2max, BMI, skinfold thickness, and physical quality of life compared to the control group. However, Tai Chi had a higher effect on resting energy expenditure and kilocalorie expenditure than walking.
population_specificity: 374 middle-aged Chinese subjects from nine geographic areas in Sha Tin.
effective_dosage: 45 minutes per day, 5 days per week (brisk walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different endothelin receptor antagonists (ERAs) on functional parameters like 6-minute walking distance in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).
results_summary: The study found that ERAs consistently reduced pulmonary vascular resistance and pulmonary arterial pressure, leading to improved 6-minute walking distance and functional status compared to placebo. However, direct comparisons between ERAs and other therapies were lacking.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acute effects of interval walking versus continuous walking on post-exercise oxygen consumption, substrate oxidation, and lipid metabolism in individuals with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Interval walking resulted in higher excess post-exercise oxygen consumption (EPOC) compared to continuous walking, but both exercise types similarly increased lipid oxidation rates and lipid metabolism markers during a post-exercise meal test.
population_specificity: Ten subjects with type 2 diabetes (7 male, 3 female; average age 60.3 years; BMI 28.3 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 60-minute sessions of either continuous walking or interval walking (3 minutes fast, 3 minutes slow).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acute glucose responses to water-based and land-based aerobic exercise (walking/running) at varying intensities relative to anaerobic threshold.
results_summary: The study found significant glycemic reductions in all sessions for both water- and land-based exercise, with no differences between groups or mesocycles, indicating that aerobic training at 85-100% of anaerobic threshold effectively lowers blood glucose regardless of environment.
population_specificity: Adults (water-based group: 54.1 ± 9.1 years; land-based group: 60.1 ± 7.3 years)
effective_dosage: 35 minutes per session at 85-90%, 90-95%, and 95-100% of anaerobic threshold across three mesocycles

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an Internet-mediated, pedometer-based walking intervention could improve health-related quality of life and daily step counts in veterans with COPD over 12 months.
results_summary: The intervention showed significant improvements in daily step counts at 4 months, but these effects diminished by 12 months, with no lasting impact on health-related quality of life or step counts. Pedometer adherence and website engagement declined over time.
population_specificity: Veterans with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), predominantly male (93.7%), mean age 67 years.
effective_dosage: Participants were instructed to wear a pedometer daily and upload step counts weekly; no specific step-count goals were mentioned.

study_goal: The study aimed to investigate factors associated with receiving anti-osteoporosis treatment (AOT) among patients with minimal trauma hip fracture admitted to an Australian tertiary trauma center.
results_summary: The study found that 45% of patients received AOT, with factors like higher serum vitamin D levels and trochanteric fractures increasing the likelihood, while living in a residential aged care facility and higher comorbidity burden decreased it. Premorbid walking ability did not correlate with treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with minimal trauma hip fracture admitted to an Australian tertiary trauma center under the Acute Orthogeriatric Service.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the time to clinical resolution of Charcot neuroarthropathy (CN) when treated with a total contact plaster cast (TCC) versus a removable below-knee boot.
results_summary: The study found that 84% of patients achieved remission, with no significant difference in resolution time between TCC and removable boot treatments. However, 34.9% of patients using the removable device required re-casting due to clinical deterioration.
population_specificity: 50 patients with acute Charcot neuroarthropathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance of Argus II subjects on three real-world functional vision tasks, including Walking Direction Discrimination, to assess the system's effectiveness.
results_summary: Subjects performed significantly better on all tasks with the Argus II system ON compared to OFF, with statistically significant improvements in Sock Sorting, Sidewalk Tracking, and Walking Direction Discrimination tasks.
population_specificity: Twenty-eight profoundly blind individuals using the Argus II retinal prosthesis system.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a lifestyle intervention, including increased walking, in improving diet, physical activity, and cardiovascular risk factors among residents of the southeastern US.
results_summary: The intervention led to substantial improvements in walking (64 min/week increase) and systolic blood pressure (-6.4 mmHg), which were generally maintained over 24 months, though weight loss was modest.
population_specificity: Residents of the southeastern US, predominantly female (77%), African American (65%), with a mean age of 56 years and mean BMI of 36 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of a 6-month home-based exercise training program (including cycling) on fitness, muscle, and motor function in patients with facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy (FSHD).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in peak oxygen uptake (+19%), muscle endurance, maximal quadriceps strength, 6-minute walking distance, and reduced fatigue, without exacerbating dystrophic pathophysiology. Similar benefits were observed in both the initial training group and the delayed control group.
population_specificity: Patients with facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy (FSHD) (n=16).
effective_dosage: Cycling 3 times weekly for 35 minutes (combination of strength, high-intensity interval, and low-intensity aerobic).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Tai Chi, conventional pulmonary rehabilitation (PR), and a combination of both, versus usual care, in improving health-related quality of life and other outcomes in patients with stable COPD.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Walking, as the study focuses on Tai Chi and conventional PR.
population_specificity: Patients with stable chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of supervised exercise three times a week.
study_duration: 8 weeks of intervention, with follow-ups until 12 months after recruitment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of drug-eluting balloons (DEBs) compared with uncoated balloon angioplasty in treating symptomatic lower-limb peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: DEBs showed better outcomes in primary vessel patency, binary restenosis, and target lesion revascularization for up to 12 months compared to uncoated balloon angioplasty, but no significant difference in clinical endpoints like amputation, death, or functional walking ability.
population_specificity: People with symptomatic lower-limb peripheral arterial disease (PAD), including intermittent claudication or critical limb ischemia.
study_duration: Follow-up ranged from 6 months to 5 years, with most trials reporting 12-month outcomes.

study_goal: To compare the effects of robot-assisted gait training (RAGT) versus conventional walking training (CWT) on gait competencies, global ability, fatigue, and spasticity in severely affected multiple sclerosis (MS) patients.
results_summary: RAGT showed significantly higher clinical improvement in gait ability and functional ambulation compared to CWT. It also improved global ability, mobility, disease severity, and perceived fatigue.
population_specificity: 43 severely affected (EDSS 6-7.5), non-autonomous ambulant MS in-patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and propose future directions for robot-aided assessment methods for lower extremities sensorimotor functions and walking in neurorehabilitation.
results_summary: The study highlights the limitations of traditional clinical assessments and contrasts them with the potential of robotic devices to provide more objective, sensitive, and reliable measurements for walking and lower extremity functions. It proposes future research directions to integrate robot-aided assessments into clinical practice.
population_specificity: Patients requiring neurorehabilitation for lower extremities sensorimotor functions and walking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a 6-month treatment with L-citrulline and metformin is more effective than placebo in preventing loss of motor function and muscle degeneration in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) patients.
results_summary: The study found that L-citrulline and metformin showed consistent changes in muscular metabolism, raising NO levels and mitochondrial protein expression in skeletal muscle tissue, but the primary endpoint (MFM D1 subscore change) and secondary outcomes (e.g., 6-minute walking test) were not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Ambulant patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) aged as per the study criteria, recruited from Switzerland, Germany, and Austria.

study_goal: To understand the journey of nursing home residents following hip fracture and evaluate the impact of an outreach rehabilitation program on their recovery, including return to walking.
results_summary: The study found that nursing home residents with dementia received poor post-operative care, with issues in pain management and mobilisation. Those with access to a geriatrician and additional therapy encountered fewer problems, suggesting better outcomes for walking recovery.
population_specificity: Older nursing home residents who recently returned from hospital following hip fracture, including those with dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence on whether volunteers can effectively help mobilize older acute medical inpatients to improve mobility outcomes.
results_summary: The review found limited scientific evidence but noted positive reports from quality improvement initiatives regarding patient and staff satisfaction with volunteer-assisted mobilization.
population_specificity: Older acute medical inpatients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of soluble guanylate cyclase (sGC) stimulators in improving walking distance (6MWD) and other outcomes in patients with pulmonary hypertension.
results_summary: sGC stimulators showed a mean increase in six-minute walking distance (6MWD) of 30.13 meters overall, with significant improvement in chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH) but no effect in pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) unless phosphodiesterase inhibitors were excluded. Mortality and serious adverse events showed no significant difference compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary hypertension of various subtypes (PAH, CTEPH, left heart disease-associated PH), all ages and severities.
interactions: Contraindicated with phosphodiesterase-V inhibitors or nitrates due to risk of hypotension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of abdominal binder usage on mobility (measured by walking distance) and pain in patients undergoing major abdominal surgery.
results_summary: The study found that using an abdominal binder increased patient mobility (walking distance) on the fourth and seventh days post-surgery and reduced pain scores compared to the control group. No significant effect was observed on gastrointestinal or pulmonary function.
population_specificity: 84 patients who underwent major abdominal surgery at a military education and research hospital in Ankara, Turkey.
study_duration: Evaluated on the first, fourth, and seventh days post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Bosentan improves cardiac function and exercise tolerance (measured via 6-min walking distance) in Fontan surgery patients.
results_summary: Bosentan significantly improved cardiac function and 6-min walking distance compared to the control group, with no mortality observed in either group. It also improved NYHA functional status but showed no other benefits.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent the Fontan procedure for complex congenital heart disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of pirfenidone on disease progression in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis patients, stratified by baseline lung function, including changes in 6-minute walking distance (6MWD).
results_summary: The study found that pirfenidone had a comparable treatment effect on disease progression (including 6MWD) in patients with both more and less preserved baseline lung function, supporting its use regardless of disease stage.
population_specificity: Patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (n=1247), stratified by baseline FVC ≥80% vs. <80% or GAP stage I vs. II-III.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the prognostic usefulness of various physical performance tests, including walking-related measures, for predicting mortality in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that slow gait speed, 6-Minute Walking Test (6MWT), and Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB) were significant predictors of mortality in older adults, with 6MWT showing the highest predictive value in men and SPPB in women.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (mean age not specified, but participants were from the Progetto Veneto Anziani study).
effective_dosage: Not specified (physical performance tests were measured, not administered as interventions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to adapt a falls management exercise program for visually impaired older people (VIOP) and assess its feasibility for a future definitive trial.
results_summary: The study focused on adapting an exercise program (FaME) for VIOP, measuring recruitment rates, adherence, fear of falling, and quality of life, but specific efficacy results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Visually impaired older people (VIOP) aged 60 and over, living at home, ambulant with or without a walking aid.
study_duration: 28 months (total study duration; intervention duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of pharmacological interventions on gait in Parkinson's disease, focusing on different components of mobility and freezing of gait.
results_summary: Levodopa and levodopa-enhancing drugs improved spatial characteristics of straight-ahead gait, while drugs targeting the acetylcholine system might enhance gait stability. However, complex walking abilities like turning and gait adaptability lack well-designed studies, and some medications worsen gait and postural stability.
population_specificity: People with Parkinson's disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if high-frequency rTMS combined with Lokomat gait training improves functional outcomes in early gait rehabilitation for motor incomplete SCI subjects.
results_summary: The study found that real rTMS combined with gait training significantly improved lower and upper extremity motor scores, with greater improvement in the real rTMS group compared to sham. However, no significant differences were observed in gait velocity, cadence, step length, or WISCI-II between groups at follow-up.
population_specificity: Motor incomplete spinal cord injury (SCI) subjects capable of over-ground walking.
effective_dosage: One daily session of 20 Hz rTMS over the vertex for 20 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of a behavioral intervention to increase physical activity, including walking, in coronary heart disease patients not attending structured rehabilitation programs.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased walking frequency, duration, and intensity compared to the control group, with notable improvements in blood pressure, BMI, exercise self-efficacy, and quality of life. Effect sizes for walking outcomes ranged from 0.05 to 0.36.
population_specificity: Patients with coronary heart disease in Jordan, Middle East, not attending structured cardiac rehabilitation programs.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included consultation, calls, and text messages, but no explicit walking dosage).
